key_points: Facebook and Instagram removed over 20 million posts for COVID-19 misinformation since the pandemic began.
The company finds measuring the prevalence of COVID-19 misinformation more complex compared to other content types.
Guy Rosen, Facebook's vice president of integrity, highlighted the challenges in defining and measuring misinformation prevalence.
The action follows criticism from the White House, which accused Facebook of allowing vaccine misinformation to spread.
Despite actions against prominent misinformation spreaders, the White House criticizes Facebook for not being transparent.
Facebook employs fact-checkers, redirects users to authoritative sources, and labels misinformation, though its effectiveness is debated.
Facebook has criteria for removing posts making false claims about COVID-19 and vaccines, recently adding new false claims to the list.
Over 3,000 accounts, pages, and groups have been removed for violating COVID-19 and vaccine misinformation policies.
Facebook claims vaccine hesitancy among US users has dropped by 50%, with increases in vaccine acceptance reported in France, Indonesia, and Nigeria.
Facebook shared viewership data of domains and posts, emphasizing disparities in narrative regarding engagement with right-wing sites.
spokespersons: Guy Rosen (Vice President of Integrity, Facebook)
